examples.0: Screams a lot, but can on occasion get their points across through a combination of grunts and wild arm waving.
examples.1: Can clearly and concisely gump technical issues and lead engineering discussions.
examples.2: Regularly convinces rooms of people to go against their best interests. Was a used car salesman in another life.

examples.0: Has no idea what they are doing. Probably shouldn't be an engineer.
examples.1: Commits code and contributes to the team. Needs guidance to meet the quality standards of the team.
examples.2: Can complete tasks quickly and with mimimal or no quality assurance failures.
examples.3: Consistently delivers ahead of schedule and to a degree of quality above most others.

B1.competency: Learns and stays up to date on new technologies

examples.0: Is aware of modern technologies such as dial-up modems and fortran
examples.2: Stays current on new technology and understands the risks and weighs the benefits on if and when to introduce them.
examples.3: Has published four thousand node and react packages on NPM.

examples.0: Is really good at hitting computers until they do what they want.
examples.1: Can turn it off then on again.
examples.2: Has experience with debuggers, profilers, and other tools used for troubleshooting software.
examples.3: Know the code at a level most others could only dream of. Obssessed with understanding how things tick.

examples.0: Understands the right questions to ask and where to seek the answers.
examples.1: Works with analysts to analyze a problem from every angle and dives deep into documentation and problems to find the best solution.
examples.2: Often tells analysts how to do their jobs and create good specs.
examples.3: Specs? Where we're going we don't need specs.
